Ravana sought vengeance against Rama and Lakshmana to avenge the disrespect shown to his sister, Shurpanakha

column11: This is the place where Sita Mata used to come for a bath and spend time, when she was kept under arrest by Ravana. The "kund" or the water collected naturally here, is known as the place where she used to have her daily bath. There is Ganesha, Hanuman, Vishnu and Rama temples also built in this premises. Behind the temple, there are sme rock formations resembling someone's huge feet. It is none other than Lord Hanuman, who went to Lanka with the sole mission of rescuing her. The premises is spick-and-span clean just like any other place in Sri Lanka and very much unlike our North Indian and West Indian temples. You can spend some quality time here and then move ahead to the botanical gardens, which I suppose must have been the earlier Ashoka Vatika, seeing the way in which the various plants are kept.

column11: This place is of historic and spiritual importance. It is believed to be the place where Sitha, God Rama's wife, was held captive by the King Ravana. This is my third visit to the place. Situated alongside a stream full of crystal clear water (this time muddy flash floods due to heavy rains) this place offers a great spiritual experience. On the other side of the stream there is a giant footprint believed to be that of Hanuman, which is accessible via a bridge over the stream. People believe that the water running in the stream has medicinal powers and want to get in touch with it. There is a hilly area on the other side of the stream which is also said to be full of medicinal plants. Some relate this to the medicinal hill (Shranjeewi Parvatham) brought by Hanuman to give life to Lakhshman, the younger brother of Rama, who was apparently died in the war against Ravana. I also felt a good fragrance,  which the villagers said is from the Eucalyptus trees of the hill. The statues were of great craftsmanship and the whole place gives a great feel. Seetha Amman is believed to be very mighty and you should visit the temple with pure mind and body. The Hindu villagers said it is ethically prohibited to visit temples after consuming Non Vegetarian food and liquors. Must visit this place if you need some relaxation, spirituality and peace of mind. The temple is in just 10 minutes driving distance from the heart of the Nuwara Eliya town.

column11: One of our most significant visits in Nuwara Eliya was the Aśoka Vana in Sītā Eliya. Here, at the Sītā Amman Kồvil, a quaint little Kồvil, we had the MOST DIVINE DARŚAN of ŚRĪ SĪTĀ DÉVI (to Whom primarily this Kồvil is dedicated) - ŚRĪ RĀMA - ŚRĪ LAKŞMAṆA - ŚRĪ HANUMĀN and ŚRĪ SUGRĪVA. At this very  location Śrī Sītā Dévi - Divine Consort of Lord ŚRĪ RĀMA - was held captive in hiding by the demon King Rāvaṇa of Lanka. When I visited this spot about 25 years ago while on a professional visit there was no structure worth the name and it seemed a total lack of respect for Śrī Sītā Dévi, on the part of the then Sri Lankan government authorities. But now, it is such a big complex that has been beautified so well! There is a small stream behind the Temple where Śrī Sītā Dévi is said to take Her bath. A bridge across the stream takes us to the spot where she was seated and being engaged in conversation by Śrī Hanumānji. The scenario was re-created by live model statues of Śrī Sītā Dévi and Śrī Hanumān. This is the only Temple in the whole world that is dedicated to Śrī Sītā Dévi, but the Sanctum Sanctorum consists of the idols of Lord Śrī Rāma, Śrī Sītā Dévi, Śrī Lakşmaṇa and Śrī Sugrīva. Just on the opposite side of the main temple complex is the Temple dedicated to Śrī Ānjanéya, facing his Lord Śrī Rāma. Out of the 13 Palaces of Rāvaṇa, two caves in the Strict Nature Reserve of Hakgala, starting from the Temple land and the cave at Ella, close to the mighty (1080 feet in height) waterfall “Rāvaṇa-Ella” where Rāvaṇa went for bathing, are supposed to be the three places where Śrī Sītā Dévi was kept in hiding. There are other deities in the complex. When we reached there, the day being Śrī Saraswati Puja Day of the Dasara, there were lots of Hindu school children who were performing pūja to a big photo of Goddess Śrī  Saraswati Dévi, placed in the Main Temple. We had to wait till their pūja was over before our offerings were accepted. In all, it was a very very fulfilling occasion and our hearts were satiated with UNTOLD JOY being in such HOLY SURROUNDINGS that were in effect – scenes from the Holy Epic Śrīmad Rāmāyaṇa that we mentally visualized and felt supremely happy being devoted to Lord Śrī Rāma – Śrī Sītā – Śrī Lakşmaṇa and Śrī Hanumān.  It was our singular luck that we were blessed with the Most Unique Divine Darśan at this MOST SACRED SPOT IN SRI LANKA!

column11: Must visit as this temple has a mythological significance in Indian culture and religion. The stream that runs from the hill, catered to the needs of Sita devi during her stay at Ashok Vatika. She is said to have bathed in this stream. About a century ago of three idols were discovered in the stream, one of which was that of Sita. It is believed that the idols have been worshipped at this spot for centuries. Now there is temple for Rama, Sita devi, Luxshmana, and Hanuman by the side of this stream. It is interesting to note that foot prints akin to Hanuman’s are found by this river and some are of small size and some are of large size, which tells us of the immense powers of hanuman transforming himself into any size.
